Worcester Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering', 'Senior Adjunct Fellow', 'Managing Director', 'Managing Director\nCore Capital', 'The Big Roads', 'An Assessment of the Near-Term Viability of Accommodating Wireless Broadband Systems', 'Second Interim Progress Report on the Ten-Year Plan and Timetable', 'Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012', 'FCC Technical Advisory Council', 'Alfred Mann Foundation', 'Transitioning to the new spectrum architecture described in this report also implies a transformation of the way that spectrum use yields Federal revenue', 'In the past few decades, the two models for giving private users spectrum access—long-term licensed and short-term unlicensed—have been undeniably successful', 'A crucial element of the spectrum policy that this report proposes is that it must create the conditions that will foster a vibrant marketplace that can accommodate the widest range of users, from initial venture-funded startups to established service providers', 'As this report has emphasized, we do not expect that there will be significant future net revenues from the clearing of Federal spectrum.', 'The Utility Spectrum Crisis: A Critical Need to Enable Smart Grids', 'The President establish an advisory mechanism, similar to the Advanced Manufacturing Partnership (AMP) Steering Committee', 'In technology sectors, the first movers capture the bulk of the lifetime profits and those profits fund the development of continuing leadership. The Nation must start to change course now to reap the full economic benefits of Federal spectrum.', "The President issue an Executive Order to prioritize 1,000 MHz of Federal spectrum for review and implementation to create the Nation's first shared-use spectrum superhighways. Description: The report discusses strategies for the U.S. government to share underutilized spectrum to spur economic growth. It emphasizes the importance of maximizing access to spectrum and creating a market that can accommodate a range of users. The report also explores ways to enhance commercial access to spectrum while ensuring the protection of Federal operations from interference.
Publisher: Executive Office of the President President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology
Subject: Spectrum Management, Economic Growth, Wireless Technology

Description: This is a letter report from the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology (PCAST) to the President regarding untreated hearing loss, especially in older Americans. It focuses on devices to assist Americans with age-related, progressive, mild-to-moderate hearing loss and suggests simple actions by the Federal Government could dramatically enhance the pace of innovation and level of competition in this domain, leading to rapid decrease in cost and improvement in capability, convenience, and use of assistive hearing devices.

Description: This document discusses biotechnology and biological threats, focusing on the new landscape, the potential for intentional misuse, and implications for biodefense strategy. Furthermore, it highlights the need for a Public Health Emergency Response Fund and provides recommendations for near-, medium-, and long-term objectives.

PCAST finds that without rapid and coordinated action, the Nation risks losing the tremendous public health progress made over the last century from the discovery and development of antibiotic drugs, thereby threatening patient care, economic growth, public health, agriculture, economic security, and national security.

Title: AN ADDENDUM TO THE PCAST REPORT ON FORENSIC SCIENCE IN CRIMINAL COURTS
People and Organizations: PCAST, President, Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), Department of Justice (DOJ), Organization of Scientific Area Committees' Friction Ridge Subcommittee (OSAC FRS), John Butler of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), INTERPOL, International Association for Identification (IAI), Harold Ruslander, Lesley Hammer, Organization of Scientific Area Committees' Materials Subcommittee (OSAC MS), Sandra Koch, Fellow of the American Board of Criminalistics (Hairs and Fibers), Houck and Budowle, Stephen Bunch, Organization of Scientific Area Committee's Firearms and Toolmarks Subcommittee (OSAC FTS), Defense Forensic Science Center (DFSC), Ames Laboratory, Miami-Dade, John Buckleton, Mark Perlin, Keith Inman, Norah Rudin and Kirk Lohmueller, American Association for the Advancement of Science
Description: This document is an addendum to the PCAST report on forensic science in criminal courts, addressing input received from stakeholders. It focuses on forensic feature-comparison methods and the requirement for empirical testing, evaluating empirical evidence for various methods and responses to the PCAST report. Key issues discussed include the necessity of empirical studies, the importance of other kinds of studies, and the completeness of PCAST's evaluation of bitemark analysis, footwear analysis, microscopic hair comparison, firearms analysis, and DNA analysis of complex mixtures.
Subject: Forensic Science, Criminal Courts, Feature-Comparison Methods, Empirical Testing, Scientific Validity, Reliability

It includes actions, concurrences, and comments due by COB 11/23. It addresses teacher quality, curriculum development, national education standards, and the role of the federal government in promoting educational excellence and equity. The report also includes data on doctoral degrees awarded in science and engineering fields by racial/ethnic group.

Molitoris', 'Ashish Sen', 'Ken Wykle', 'President Clinton', 'National Science and Technology Council (NSTC)', 'Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP)', 'RAND Corporation', 'Transportation Research Board (TRB)', 'U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT)', 'Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)', 'US Coast Guard', 'Federal Highway Administration (FHWA)', 'Federal Railroad Administration (FRA)', 'Federal Transit Administration (FTA)', 'Maritime Administration (MARAD)', 'National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA)', 'Research and Special Programs Administration (RSPA)', 'Department of Commerce (DOC)', 'National Institute for Standards and Technology (NIST)', 'National Weather Service', 'Department of Defense (DoD)', 'Defense Advanced Research Project Agency', 'Department of Energy (DOE)', 'Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)', 'National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA)', 'National Science Foundation (NSF)']
Description: This document outlines the National Science and Technology Council (NSTC) Subcommittee on Transportation R&D's assessment of Federal research relevant to transportation. It defines 'Enabling Research' and details six categories: Human Performance and Behavior; Advanced Materials and Structures; Computer, Information, and Communication Systems; Energy, Propulsion, and Environmental Engineering; Sensing and Measurement; and Analysis, Modeling, Design, and Construction Tools. The plan identifies the Federal research community, R&D funding overview, and discusses future directions and priorities.

Description: The PCAST will brief the President on several pending Science and Technology issues that will be especially relevant in the upcoming months.
